docs.title: 🏠 Welcome to the Hydrust Wiki
docs.text:
Hydrust is a modular media orchestration engine designed for performance, safety, and long-term maintainability. This wiki serves as the technical source of truth for the project's internals, SDK, and plugin ecosystem.

This documentation is under heavy development and it is not in any way complete or representative.

docs.title: 🏗️ The Hydrust Paradigm
docs.text: Unlike traditional scrapers that rely on monolithic scripts, Hydrust utilizes a Host-Guest Architecture. This separates the volatile logic of site-specific scraping from the high-performance stability of the media engine.

docs.title: 🧩 Core Components
docs.text:
• The Host (Rust): The "Engine Room." Handles GStreamer pipelines, network orchestration, and the DRM lifecycle.
  • The Guest (WASM): The "Site Logic." Sandboxed modules that navigate APIs and manifests to find media sources.
  • The WIT (Interface): The "Contract." A strictly typed communication layer that ensures the Host and Guest can exchange data safely without memory leaks.

docs.title: 🤝 Project Roles & Permissions
docs.text:
Hydrust is a community-driven effort. We utilize a tier-based progression system synchronized with our Discord Server.

  • 📦 Uncompiled: New arrivals observing the tree.
  • 🏗️ Linkers: Active contributors providing logs and bug reports.
  • 🧩 Plugin Masters: Developers maintaining verified WASM extensions.
  • 🌟 Core Architects: Project maintainers with write access to the Host Engine.

docs.title: ⚖️ Legal Policy
docs.text: Hydrust is provided for educational and personal archival purposes only. Contributors and users are expected to respect the copyright laws and Terms of Service of the platforms they interact with. For more details, see our Legal Disclaimer.

docs.title: Welcome to the mission!
docs.text:
Whether you're here to harden the Host Engine or expand the Guest Plugin ecosystem, here is your path to your first contribution:

Plugin only development

You do not need to setup development enviroment if you are intrested in only building plugins. Please follow Plugin Developer Guide for more information.

docs.title: Set up development enviroment
docs.text:
Github repository: https://github.com/razorblade23/hydrust.git

  1. Setup & Environment
  2. [x] Prerequisites: Docker (or Podman) and VS Code with DevContainers extension installed
  3. [x] Clone the repository: Fork and clone the Hydrust repository.
  4. [x] Build devcontainer: A popup should appear in the bottom-right corner asking to "Reopen in Container". Click it!

  5. [x] Wait for the magic: VS Code will now pull a specialized Rust image and install all the GStreamer headers for you automatically

  6. Choose Your Path

  7. [ ] The "Host" Track: Head over to <#1469126920036683786> if you want to work on GStreamer, muxing logic, or the Rust core.
  8. [ ] The "Guest" Track: Head over to <#1469127023145390110> if you want to build or maintain site-specific scrapers.

  9. [ ] The "Scribe" Track: Browse <#1469150932745977949> for any threads tagged with 📝 WIP that need more detail.

  10. Your First Contribution (The "Low-Hanging Fruit")

  11. [ ] Audit a Plugin: Pick a site plugin in the library and verify if it still works with the latest site layout.
  12. [ ] Documentation: Found a step in the setup that was confusing? Open a thread in <#1469150932745977949> with the fix.

  13. [ ] Test Drive: Run the engine against a high-concurrency manifest and report any panics in <#1469130877077291122> .

  14. Join the Conversation

  15. [ ] Introduce yourself in <#1469101324632068329> .
  16. [ ] Check the <#1469125575120654336> to see what architectural changes are being debated.

docs.title: 🧩 Building Guest Modules
docs.text:
The Hydrust SDK allows developers to create high-performance, sandboxed media scrapers using Rust and WebAssembly.

Instead of writing brittle scripts, you are building Guest Modules that interface directly with the Hydrust Host Engine.

Using rust is not the only option

You can use any programming language that compiles to WASM. There is a feature goal of providing several other SDK libraries in varius languages.

docs.title: 🏗️ The Host-Guest Relationship
docs.text:
In the Hydrust ecosystem, responsibilities are strictly decoupled:

  • The Host: Manages the heavy lifting - network requests, GStreamer pipelines, and DRM decryption.
  • The Guest (You): Contains the "Intelligence" - parsing HTML/JSON, discovering manifests (HLS/DASH), and handling site-specific authentication logic.

Communication happens over the WIT (WebAssembly Interface Type) layer, ensuring that even if a plugin crashes, the Host Engine remains stable.

docs.title: 🛠️ Prerequisites
docs.text:
To build Hydrust plugins, you need the following tools installed on your development machine:

  1. Rust Toolchain: Install Rust
  2. Add Hydrust CLI (Optional but Recommended): Our tooling automates the scaffolding of new plugins. 
    cargo install hydrust-cli

Hydrust CLI is not yet available

Hydrust CLI is still in active development and not yet available as a tool. The following guide assumes manual build process.

docs.title: 📂 Plugin Structure
docs.text: A standard Hydrust plugin is a specialized Rust library. - Your Cargo.toml must specify cdylib to ensure it compiles to a standalone WASM module. - You also need our hydrust-sdk as a dependancy.

docs.title: 📜 The "Contract" (WIT)
docs.text: Every plugin must implement the interfaces defined in our provider.wit file. This is the "contract" that tells the engine your plugin is compatible.

docs.title: Create and initialize new project
docs.text:
cargo new --lib my-hydrust-plugin
cd my-hydrust-plugin
cargo install cargo-component

docs.title: Configure Cargo.toml
docs.text:
Set the crate type to cdylib and add the SDK: cargo add hydrust-sdk

[lib]
crate-type = ["cdylib"]

[dependencies]
hydrust-sdk = "0.1.2"

docs.title: Implement the Plugin
docs.text:
Edit src/lib.rs to handle events from the Hydrust Core:

use hydrust_sdk::{register_plugin, Handler};
use hydrust_sdk::events::Event;
use hydrust_sdk::metadata::PluginInfo;

#[derive(Default)]
struct MyPlugin;

impl Handler for MyPlugin {
    fn metadata(&self) -> PluginInfo {
        PluginInfo {
            name: "My Plugin".to_string(),
            version: "0.1.0".to_string(),
            author: "MyName".to_string(),
            description: "My plugin does wonders".to_string()
        }
    }

    fn on_event(&self, event: Event) {
        // Handle event logic here
    }
}

register_plugin!(MyPlugin);

docs.title: Compile your plugin
docs.text:
To compile your plugin run the following command: 

cargo component build --release

This will produce a binary in your ./target/wasm32-wasip1/release directory with a file extension .wasm.

This is all you need to load it into Hydrust
